text:
Has anybody seen this: <https://www.quantamagazine.org/new-algorithm-breaks-speed-limit-for-solving-linear-equations-20210308/|New Algorithm Breaks Speed Limit for Solving Linear Equations>. Paper is here <https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.10254|arXiv:2007.10254>.

It is a new randomized algorithm that (for sparse matrices) it implements matrix multiplication faster than O(n^2.37).

attachments.title: New Algorithm Breaks Speed Limit for Solving Linear Equations
attachments.text: By harnessing randomness, a new algorithm achieves a fundamentally novel — and faster — way of performing one of the most basic computations in math and computer science.
attachments.fallback: Quanta Magazine: New Algorithm Breaks Speed Limit for Solving Linear Equations

attachments.title: Solving Sparse Linear Systems Faster than Matrix Multiplication
attachments.text: Can linear systems be solved faster than matrix multiplication? While there has been remarkable progress for the special cases of graph structured linear systems, in the general setting, the bit...
attachments.fallback: arXiv.org: Solving Sparse Linear Systems Faster than Matrix Multiplication

elements.text: New Algorithm Breaks Speed Limit for Solving Linear Equations

.

It is a new randomized algorithm that (for sparse matrices) it implements matrix multiplication faster than O(n^2.37).

text: I read it yesterday, yes. I don't recall seeing any implementation though

text: Is there going to be a race to implement this in Julia?

text: I wonder if it is possible to derandomize.

elements.text: I wonder if it is possible to derandomize.
